Box 1401, FIN-02044 VIT, Finland Received 24 August 1995; revised 18 March 1996; accepted 18 March 1996 Abstract The decarbonylation of C04_nRhn(CO)12/SiO2 and (Co4(C0)12-I-Rh4(CO)12)/SiO2 cata- lysts was studied by temperature programmed reduction (TPR) and in-situ diffuse reflectance FT-IR techniques. Special attention was paid to the effect of the decomposition atmosphere on the supported catalysts. The temperature of decarbonylation depended on the precursor, and the CO desorption peak maxima during the TPR were as follows: Co2Rh2(CO)12 = 123, Co3Rh(CO)12 = 125, (Co4(C0)12--}-Rh4(CO)x2) = 135, Co4(C0)12 : 137 and Rh4(CO)I2 = 178. The CO desorption was greatest for C04(CO)12, and less and similar for other catalysts. Thus, from rhodium containing catalysts less CO was desorbed at elevated temperatures indicating a stronger interaction of rhodium than of cobalt with the support. Correspondingly, according to FT-IR measurements, the stability of the tetranuclear carbonyls supported on silica decreased in the order Co4(CO)12 > bimetallic carbonyls > Rh4(CO)I2 at room temperature. Keywords." Rhodium; Cobalt; FT-IR; Tetranuclear carbonyls 1. Introduction Molecular metal clusters are increasingly being used as precursors for sup- ported catalysts because they produce small metallic particles at relatively low decomposition temperatures [1]. In this way, supported zero valent metallic * Corresponding author. KiL, iaho et al. / Applied Catalysis A: General 144 (1996) 93-109 particles can be obtained without exposing the catalysts to the high temperatures normally required for other catalyst precursors, and agglomeration is prevented. Thus, it is also possible to prepare layered catalyst structures consisting of metal clusters dispersed on the surface of a reducible metal oxide that is supported on alumina or silica [1]. The wide variation in the activity of catalysts derived from carbonyl precur- sors has been related to differences in the preparation of the support [2]. The hydroxyl groups on the surface of the untreated hydroxylated support have been observed to act as adsorption sites for the metal carbonyls leading to oxidised active species during the decomposition of the carbonyl [1,3,4]. However, thermal pretreatment progressively eliminates the hydroxyl groups of the sup- port, and after this dehydroxylation it has been possible to prepare well-disper- sed and well-reduced catalysts [4]. The thermal pretreatment together with the type of the silica determine the detailed hydroxyl structure of the support. Water is removed from porous silica at approx. 200 and any further increase in the heat treatment temperature initiates dehydroxylation [5]. First the H-bonded OH groups and thereafter the isolated OH groups are removed giving rise to siloxane bridges with different rates of strain [5]. The OH groups present on the partially dehydroxylated silica surfaces are weakly acidic in nature, and with suitable bases they form hydrogen bonded adducts stable only at -196 [6]. On a fully dehydroxylated silica support the adsorption of the carbonyl precursor is mainly physical in nature [6]. Thus, the interaction between the clusters and the dehydroxylated silica support is weak [7-9] allowing the metal-metal interaction to dominate over the metal-support interaction [6]. Carbonyl cluster derived catalysts may be deposited on the dehydroxylated support by dry-mixing, impregnation or adsorption. Since most of the metal carbonyl clusters are oxygen sensitive, bimetallic catalysts have generally been prepared by impregnation from various organic solvents [7,10] under inert atmosphere. After impregnation the solvent is evaporated and the carbonyl is thermally decomposed. The thermal decomposition has been carried out under vacuum [11], oxygen [7], inert gas [10,12], hydrogen [11-13], CO [11] or synthesis gas [14], and the decomposition atmosphere has been found to significantly influence the stability of the carbonyl on the silica support [11] as well as dispersion and activity of the catalysts [7,12,14-17]. Results pertaining to the decomposition of metal carbonyls on silica are somewhat contradictory. Anderson et al. [7] have observed that the hydrogen uptake of Co2Rh2(CO)12/SiO2 catalyst is higher when the catalyst is decom- posed under oxygen than when it is decomposed under nitrogen. However, oxidation is to be avoided if the original clusters are to be preserved, and calcination before reduction is probably undesirable if highly dispersed reducible clusters are required [18]. For example, Xiao et al. [16] calcined Co4(CO)12 derived catalysts before reduction and found the catalysts fairly inactive for CO J. Kiviaho et al. / Applied Catalysis A: General 144 (1996) 93-109 95 hydrogenation, whereas we obtained high activity for the same catalyst in the absence of calcination [17]. Guczi et al. [12,15] have observed that both the dispersion and activity of Fe-Ru carbonyl catalysts are better when the catalysts are decomposed under He than when they are decomposed under H 2. Under He flow about 20-40% of carbon evolved during the decomposition remains on the catalyst and stabilises the dispersion [12]. Huang et al. [11] state, however, that oxidation of the active rhodium species on silica is better avoided in the presence of hydrogen. Moreover, Huang et al. [11] ascribed the stabilisation of the carbonyl precursor to the presence of CO in the gas mixture. However, in case of C%(CO)s supported on zirconium-promoted alumina Withers et al. [ 14] have observed that activation with hydrogen significantly improved both activity and liquid fuel selectivity relative to activation with synthesis gas (CO/H2 = 1) in a slurry test. The increased activity was tentatively attributed to a higher degree of cobalt reduction, but enhanced selectivity could not be explained. The present study deals with the decomposition of Co4_nRhn(CO)t2/SiO2 and (Co4(CO)I, + Rh4(CO)12)/SiO2 catalysts, with emphasis on the effect of decomposition temperature and atmosphere on the properties of the catalysts. Temperature programmed reduction (TPR) and in-situ diffuse reflectance FT-IR techniques were used in the studies. The results are discussed also with a view to the activity of the catalysts in CO hydrogenation [17]. 2. Experimental 2.1. Preparation of the catalysts The preparation of the Co4_,Rhn(CO)12/SiO2 (where n=0,1,2,4) and (C(CO)12 + Rh4(CO)12)/SiO2 catalysts is described in detail in our previous publication [17]. Commercially available C04(CO)~2 and Rh4(CO)12 were ob- tained from Strem Chemicals. The other metal carbonyl clusters were prepared by published methods and were as follows: C02Rh2(CO)~2 and C03Rh(CO)L~ [19]. Grace 432 silica support was dried under vacuum at 600/2 h to dehydrox- ylate the surface [2,5]. The homo- or heterometallic carbonyl cluster catalysts were prepared by impregnation from nitrogenated dichloromethane solution under deoxygenated atmosphere. The metal loading of all preparations was 0.9 mmol/1 g SiO2 and the catalysts were dried slowly under vacuum at room temperature. The final metal loading was between 5 wt.-% (Co4(CO)Ie) and 8.5 wt.-% (Rh4(CO)12). Every step in the preparation of the catalysts was carried out under inert atmosphere using a glove box and nitrogen-vacuum line. In the remainder of this paper, the following abbreviations indicate the precursors: Co4 = C04(CO)12, Rh4 = Rh4(CO)12, C03Rh = C03Rh(CO)12 and C02Rh2 = C02Rh2(CO)I2. 96 J. Kiviaho et al. / Applied Catalysis A: General 144 (1996) 93-109 2.2. Temperature programmed reduction The temperature programmed reduction (TPR) studies were carried out using a down flow tubular quartz microreactor connected to a Balzers quadrupole mass spectrometer. In TPR studies a sample (300 mg) of a fresh catalyst was placed under flow of 3% H2 in Ar. The temperature of the catalysts was ramped at a linear rate of 3/min from 25 to 450. The products formed during the decomposition were detected by the mass spectrometer. Every step in the preparation of the sample was carried out under inert atmosphere using a glove box and a nitrogen-vacuum line. 2.3. FT-IR studies The IR spectra were recorded with a Perkin Elmer model 1760X FT-IR spectrometer to which an in-situ diffuse reflectance cell was coupled. The cell is designed to operate at temperatures up to 500 and pressures up to 3.5 MPa under the desired gas atmosphere. The samples were prepared by grinding a mixture of KBr [20,21] and the catalyst in 15:85 SiO2:KBr weight ratio. Catalyst samples were diluted by KBr to get better quality spectra. The amount of KBr and the grinding procedure were also optimised in terms of the energy level of the detected signal. The sample was loaded into the in-situ diffuse reflectance cell under inert atmo- sphere using a glove box, and the cell was connected to the FT-IR under flowing nitrogen. The spectra were measured by 100 scans (resolution 2 cm-l) at intervals of 10 between 30 and 250 under flowing hydrogen or carbon monoxide (0.1 MPa). The background spectrum was determined at each temper- ature from SiO2 diluted with KBr (15:85), and it was substracted from the respective recorded absorption spectrum. The interfering bands of gas phase carbon monoxide were eliminated by subtracting the spectrum of gaseous CO on the SiO2/KBr sample. Thus, the calculated spectra represent the absorbance of metal carbonyls supported on silica, or the absorbance of the species adsorbed on the metals. The spectra were converted to Kubelka-Munk units [22,23] to allow a quantitative interpretation of the data. 3. Results and discussion 3.1. Temperature programmed reduction (TPR) TPR of the CO4_nRhn/SiO2 and (Co4 --t-Rh4)/SiO2 catalysts was carried out to determine the decomposition of these supported carbonyl precursors. The decomposition was measured by the formation of carbon monoxide, carbon dioxide, methane and water and by the consumption of hydrogen, in accordance with an earlier study [24]. J. The decomposition of Co3Rh, Co2Rh2 and Rh4 in solution to give Co6_nRhn(CO)16 species has occurred already at 60, 60 and 25, respectively [19]. Thus, Rh4 may loose some carbonyls during catalyst preparation already at room temperature due to this transformation. Visual evolution of CO indicating the decomposition of the precursors Co4, Co3Rh, Co2Rh2 and Rh4 has been observed at 100, 130, 120 and 130 [19]. Furthermore, thermogravimetric analysis has indicated that under nitrogen atmosphere Rh4 starts to decompose at 90 forming Rh6(CO)16 at approx. 160 and finally metal at ca. 200 [19]. Hence, the stabilities of the studied precursors depend strongly on the solvent or gas atmosphere they are in contact with. The main reaction of all Co4_nRhJSiO: and (Co4 + Rh4)/SiO2 catalysts occurring during the thermal treatment under hydrogen atmosphere was the decarbonylation of the cluster (see Figs. 1 and 2). The extent of decarbonylation was greatest for Co4//8iO2 catalyst, and less and similar for other catalysts. Under hydrogen atmosphere the temperature of decarbonylation depended on the precursor, and the peak maxima were as follows: Co2Rh2 = 123, Co3Rh = 125, (Co4 + Rh4) = 135, Co4 = 137 and Rh4 = 178. The decarbonyla- tion of Rh4/SiO2 occurred at a significantly higher temperature than that of Co4/SiO2 and the bimetallic catalysts. The decarbonylation temperature of Rh4 was, however, lower than that observed for the precursor under nitrogen atmosphere in the absence of the support [19] probably due to the weak, but yet 98 J. This interaction is, in turn, determined by the OH distribution of the silica. The dehydroxylation at 600 still leaves some weakly acidic OH groups on the surface of the silica [5,11 ], and the precursors loose some of their carbonyl groups during the catalyst preparation at room temperature via ligand exchange with the surface hydroxyl groups. The surface siloxane bridges formed during pretreatment of the silica support do not easily undergo either nucleophilic or electrophilic attack and therefore act as centres for physical adsorption [5,6]. The decarbonylation of the precursor at room temperature depends on the stability of the precursor itself as well as on the interaction of the precursor with the support. Since the precursors under study are all stable at room temperature under inert atmosphere for long periods [19], the decarbonylation at room temperature must be due to transformation of the cluster to hexanuclear form, or the degradation of the cluster to subcarbonyls or metal through cluster-support interaction. The degree of interaction between the support and the precursor determines the amount of decarbonylation occurring at higher temperatures [25]; when the precursor interacts weakly with the support, the decarbonylation is weak during preparation and occurs mainly later above room temperature [7]. Thus, our results indicate that Rh4 and bimetallic clusters interact more strongly with SiO2 than Co4 does, because the amount of decarbonylation at elevated temperatures was much less for the Rh4/SiO2 and bimetallic/SiO2 catalysts than for the Co4/SiO2 catalyst. Yet, some of the decarbonylation at room temperature should be assigned to the transformation of the Rh4 to Rh6(CO)16 [19]. Aged catalysts All Co4_,Rh~/SiO2 catalysts were aged at room temperature under argon atmosphere. All clusters, including the mixed metal clusters, decomposed via Co6 ~Rh~(CO)16 (n--0-6) framework (bands at about 1800 cm-1) as illus- trated for Rh4 and Co4 in Fig. 1l. The total rate of decomposition to metal decreased in the order Rh4 > bimetallic catalysts > Co4. Thus, transformation of Rh4 to Rh6(CO)I6 was fast, after one day we observed sharp strong bands at 2080 and 1801 cm-1 which are typical of Rh6(CO)16 adsorbed on dehydrated silica [27]. Within 30 days the band at 1880 cm ~ had completely disappeared, indicating that all Rh4 had been transformed to Rh6(CO)t6. After 150 days a new weak band appeared at 1860 cm ~ characteristic to CO coordinated to metallic particles [27]. In comparison, for the Co4 precursor the transformation was extremely slow: after 290 days the band at 1795 cm ~ characteristic to Co6(CO)16 [29] was still very small. 3.2.3. The Rh6(CO)16 initially present on the silica support decomposed during heating and the original bands disappeared, see Fig. 10. In agreement with our results, Huang et al. [11] have observed that silica supported Rh6(CO)js decomposes notably around 100 under vacuum or hydrogen, and the decom- position was completed by 150. Theolier et al. [27] have also reported that Rh4 supported on silica is easily transformed to Rh6(CO)I6, which decomposes producing metallic particles covered with CO at elevated temperatures [27]. Our results indicate that the characteristic bands for Rh6(CO)16 initially present on the silica supported catalyst change drastically at approx. 150, which is the decomposition temperature of the Rh6(CO)16 on the support [11]. The TPR results also suggested that the decarbonylation of Rh4/SiO2 occurred at a significantly higher temperature (178) with regard to the cobalt containing catalysts. The difference in the decomposition temperature determined by TPR and FT-IR is probably due to different experimental procedures, such as different rate of heating. At this decomposition temperature of the Rh6(CO)16 the band for the bridged CO at 1801 cm-~ disappeared, whereas the shoulder at 1780 cm-~ was still observed. Above 150 the band at 1780 cm i decreased with increasing temperature, and shifted to 1750 cm-~. This shift may result from a lower CO coverage of the metal particles at high temperature as suggested by Hayden [30]. Finally, at 250, we detected only two broad bands (at 2037 and 1750 cm ~) for the RhJSiO2 catalyst assigned to terminal and bridged type CO on metallic Rh, respectively. We may assign the presence of the band at 1750 cm-I to face-bridged adsorption of CO as observed for NaY zeolite entrapped Rh~(CO) 16 by Ichikawa et al. [31] at 200. 3.2.4. Summary The decomposition and decarbonylation of Co4_nRhn(CO)j2/SiOe and (C04(CO)12 + Rh4(CO)12)/SiO2 catalysts were studied by temperature pro- grammed reduction (TPR) and in-situ diffuse reflectance FT-IR techniques. Emphasis was on elucidating the effect of decomposition temperature and atmosphere on the properties of the catalysts. The temperature of decarbonylation depended on the precursor, and the CO desorption peak maxima during TPR were as follows: Co2Rh2 = 123, Co3Rh = 125, (Co4 + Rh4) = 135, Co4 = 137 and Rh4 = 178. The amount of CO desorbed was greatest for Co4 and less and similar for the other precursors. Thus, less CO was released during decarbonylation at elevated temperature from rhodium-containing catalysts than from cobalt catalysts, indicating a stronger interaction with rhodium and the support than with cobalt and the support. In fact, according to the FT-IR results the stability of the carbonyls supported on silica decreased in the order Co4 > bimetallic carbonyls > Rh4 at room tempera- ture under argon atmosphere. Rh4 decomposed readily to Rh6(CO)16, and after 120-290 days a part of the Co4_nRh. complexes on silica was converted to Co6_ nRh n(CO)16 clusters and metals. 108 J. Kiviaho et al. / Applied Catalysis A: General 144 (1996) 93-109 The effect of decomposition atmosphere on Rh4 was determined by in-situ FT-IR measurements. Under hydrogen atmosphere the bands typical for the supported carbonyls were lost at lower temperatures than suggested by the TPR results. Under CO atmosphere the structures initially present on the silica surface were much more stable, and the decomposition occurred at a signifi- cantly higher temperature. The spectra were better retained in respect to the initial spectra in the presence of CO, and the face-bridged adsorption form of CO observed on catalysts decomposed under hydrogen was absent on catalysts decomposed under CO atmosphere. Thus, the adsorption characteristics of the catalyst depends on the atmosphere of decomposition, which merits further studies both in terms of characterisation and reactivity.
